newsitem.title: USA: Most IMM currency futures close slightly higher.
newsitem.headline: Most IMM currency futures close slightly higher.

text.p: Most IMM currency futures closed slightly higher, pulling away from the daily peaks on the heels of the passage of the U.S. balanced budget agreement by the Senate, traders said.
They said the outcome of the Senate's vote was largely expected but may have contributed to profit-taking in June yen and June marks.
"You have a lot of commercial longs," one futures trader said. "So any time prices pull back a little, you see profit-taking."

He also said firms and dealers were adjusting positions ahead of the three-day U.S. holiday weekend. Currency futures closed Friday's session at 1200 CDT/1700 GMT, and cash trading wound down about 1100 CDT/1600 GMT.
All U.S. trade will be closed on Monday. U.K. markets will also be shut on Monday.
"I'm still bullish yen, but people are just willing to sell here in the near term," another trader said, adding that one major U.S. dealer bought 1,000 June yen at $0.008680.
Once again, traders said the direction of the cash cross rates would have a significant effect on key currency futures.
Some cited the continued buying of yen against marks as a supportive factor towards June yen.
"The cash mark/yen was oversold, but there is no sign that the trend is reversing," he said.

Cash marks also fell under light pressure against Swiss francs, as the cash rate edged towards the 82.50 centime level. June Swiss francs slightly extended gains above Thursday's high of $0.7150 after trading inside Thursday's ranges for most of the morning.
June marks eased to a low of $0.5911, slightly below the pivot point of $0.5912.
Canadian and Australian dollar futures continued to grind lower. One U.S. dealer sold 1,000 June Australian dollars at $0.7680, a floor source said.

At the end of pit trade, June yen was up $0.000010 at $0.008664, marks were up $0.0001 at $0.5915, Swiss francs were up $0.0047 at $0.7146, sterling rose $0.0122 to $1.6348, Canadian dollars were off $0.0016 at $0.7285, Australian dollars were off $0.0120 at $0.7653 and Mexican pesos were off $0.000150 at $0.125850. ((Derivatives desk 312-408-8750))
